html:
Etymology[edit]

From dē- +‎ scrībō (“write”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /deːsˈkriː.boː/, [d̪eːsˈkriː.boː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /desˈkri.bo/, [d̪ɛsˈkriː.bɔ]

Verb[edit]

dēscrībō (present infinitive dēscrībere, perfect active dēscrīpsī, supine dēscrīptum); third conjugation

  1. I copy off or transcribe something from the original, write down, write out.
  2. I describe in painting or writing, draw, draw out, sketch off.
  3. (figuratively) I represent, delineate, describe.
  4. (figuratively) I mark off, establish, define, divide or distribute into parts.

Descendants[edit]

  • Catalan: descriure
  • → English: describe
  • Italian: descrivere
  • Old French: descrivre
    • French: décrire
  • Portuguese: descrever
  • Spanish: describir

References[edit]

  • describo in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • describo in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • describo in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • to draw geometrical figures: formas (not figuras) geometricas describere
    • to allude to a person or thing (not alludere): describere aliquem (Cael. 20. 50)
    • to give the state a constitution: civitati leges, iudicia, iura describere
  • describo in Ramminger, Johann (accessed 16 July 2016) Neulateinische Wortliste: Ein Wörterbuch des Lateinischen von Petrarca bis 1700‎[2], pre-publication website, 2005-2016
